description:
Neosynchiropus ocellatus is a species of fish belonging to the family Callionymidae, commonly known as the ocellated dragonet or eyespot dragonet. It is found in the Indo-Pacific region, from the Red Sea and East Africa to the Marshall Islands and northern Australia.

The Neosynchiropus ocellatus is a small, elongated fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 10 centimeters. It has a distinctive pattern of ocelli (eye-like spots) on its body, which are believed to play a role in communication and predator avoidance. The fish's coloration can vary, ranging from shades of brown and yellow to vibrant blue and green hues.

Neosynchiropus ocellatus is a benthic species, primarily inhabiting coral reefs, rocky areas, and seagrass beds at depths ranging from 3 to 40 meters. It is known to be a carnivorous species, feeding on small invertebrates and crustaceans. The reproduction and life cycle of this species are not well-studied, but it is believed to exhibit a variety of mating behaviors, including courtship displays and territoriality.

Due to its small size and specialized habitat requirements, the Neosynchiropus ocellatus is not a commercially important species, but it is of interest to marine aquarium hobbyists and researchers studying the ecology and behavior of reef-associated fishes.
